So we restrict our attention to V and ignore X, in step (2) we get v a with closure (v a) compact, and then the shrinking lemma gives you u i such that closure (u i) ‚äÜ v i. This means that closure (u i) will be compact, since it is a closed subset of a compact set.
From the perspective of X, we know that coe '' closure (v a) is compact, hence closed, so closure (coe '' v a) = coe '' closure (v a) is also compact. Similarly, closure (u a) is compact (in V), hence closure (coe '' u a) is compact (in X).
